RISK MANAGEMENT PROGRAM
MATHESON TRI-GAS A? MORROW GA FACILITY


EXECUTIVE SUMMARY

Description of Facility

The Matheson Tri-Gas, Inc. Morrow GA facility purifies and fills compressed specialty industrial gases in cylinders in both large and small quantities.  The source material gas which is transfilled and sometimes purified may be packaged in ton cylinder units (i.e. tonners) or regular cylinders, depending on the gas.  The finished product varies from a single pure chemical gas to gas mixtures, and the capacity of finished product cylinders varies from 2000 pounds to less than a few grams of gas depending on the size of the cylinder and the type of material involved.  

Accidental Release Prevention and Emergency Response Policies

Matheson Tri-Gas is committed to developing and maintaining the manpower, the equipment and the procedures necessary to prevent accidental releases of regulated chemicals.  In addition we are committed to developing and maintaining the manpower, the equipment and the emergency response procedures necessary to mitigate a release quickly and effectively if it occurs.  

Regulated Chemicals and Processes

There are 44 chemicals at the Matheson Tri-Gas Morrow facility that could potentially be regulated under the Risk Management Program (RMP).  (See Table 1)  Of the 44 chemicals, only oneA?chlorine--is present in two processes in sufficient quantity to be regulated under RMP.  The two processes are transfilling/purification and storage.

Accidental Release Prevention Program and Mitigation Measures

The major elements of the Accidental Release Prevention Program and release mitigation measures at this site are as follows:  (Each element pertains to all RMP-regulated processes at the facility.)

A?    Adherence to objective equipment standards.  One of the most significant contributors to the prevention of accidental releases at this site is the high standard to which all gas cylinders must be manufactured.  The Departme

nt of Transportation has detailed requirements for manufacturing and testing cylinders.  Cylinders must be manufactured according to a particular metallurgical standard and be able to withstand significant overfilling; increase in pressure; increase in temperature and the possibility that they will be hit or fall over.    

A?    Piping and other equipment such as tanks associated with gas processes adheres to ASTM standards.  Toxic gas processing is done in exhausted enclosures that meet ventilation standards.  All residual gas is vented to scrubbers that are constructed to meet both air emission and fire code standards.  

A?    Process hazard analysis.  Process hazard analyses are performed on relevant processes to determine potential hazards and recommendations for process improvements.  

A?    Development and implementation of standard operating procedures.  

A?    A comprehensive training program that includes classroom and on-the-job training. 

A?    A systematic preventive maintenance program.  All relevant equipment is on a schedule for inspection and inspections are documented. 

A?    A thorough accident reporting and investigation program.  The corporate accident/incident reporting and investigation procedure requires the reporting and investigation not only of incidents resulting in injuries, but also incidents that had the potential to result in an injury to an employee or a significant impact on the company's business. 

Five-Year Accident History

There has been one accidental release from RMP-regulated processes in the last five years at this facility.  A small amount of chlorine (less than 1 lb.) was released from a vent line on March 24, 2003.  One employee had minor nose and throat irritation.  The release did not damage property and did not impact people or property outside the plant boundaries.  
 
Emergency Response Program

This facility's Emergency Response Program includes:  

Identification and location of hazardous materials.  All hazardous materials ha

ve been identified, located and mapped.  A cylinder storage procedure maintains consistent locations for each material.  


A trained Emergency Response Team (ERT).  ERT members have hazardous technician level of training (24+ hours) and must go through refresher training every year.  At least four responders live within 30 minutes of the plant; their off-duty schedule is coordinated so that at least two are always available during after-work hours.  Appropriate personal protective equipment is maintained at the site for response actions.  

Evacuation procedure.  Evacuation routes and procedures have been developed and all personnel trained on them.  

Exposure limits and first aid procedures.  These are included in the MSDSs available in the Analytical Lab.

Emergency response contact list.  This list is maintained and all personnel are trained on the portions relevant to their job.

Emergency response procedure.  This procedure details the sequence of activities for various emergency scenarios: gas or fire alarm; gas release, injury, fire, liquid spill. 

Coordination with local agencies.  The facility has made sure that the local fire department is familiar with all materials, processes and monitoring equipment. The fire department has made several training visits to the facility and in the year 2000 participated in a mock drill at the site.
